abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times are always looking for the most interesting items on the Web. Today’s selection includes an analyst’s take on the idea of an Amazon phone, a look at Occupy Wall Street’s media headquarters, and some noises you just don’t hear anymore.
snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times are always looking for the most interesting items on the Web. Today’s selection includes an analyst’s take on the idea of an Amazon phone, a look at Occupy Wall Street’s media headquarters...
lead_paragraph: What the editors and reporters of The Times’s tech staff spotted on the Web:

abstract: A new teardown report from IHS iSuppli on the Kindle Fire estimates Amazon is losing less than $3 on every Kindle Fire sold. That’s a little better than IHS’s previous forecast for the device and a lot better than other analyst estimates, which had predicted Amazon would lose as much as $50 on every Kindle Fire.
snippet: A new teardown report from IHS iSuppli on the Kindle Fire estimates Amazon is losing less than $3 on every Kindle Fire sold. That’s a little better than IHS’s previous forecast for the device and a lot better than other analyst estimates, which ha...
lead_paragraph: After Amazon announced it would charge $199 for the Kindle Fire, a big question was how much — not whether — the company would lose money on every device sold. According to a new teardown report on the device, the answer is: not as much as expected.

headline.main: Kindle Fire Said to Bleed a Bit Less Red Ink
